metadata.chief_complaint: vomiting x2 days, dehydration assessment, complex orders

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Hi, I'm Dr. Patel. Noah's been vomiting?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Yes, for two days now. He can't keep anything down. I'm really worried he's getting dehydrated.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: How many times has he vomited today?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: At least six times. Every time he drinks anything, it comes right back up.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Any diarrhea?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: A little. Maybe two loose stools today.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Fever?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Low grade, around 100 yesterday. I haven't checked today.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: How many wet diapers or trips to the bathroom to pee?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: He's only peed once today and it was small and dark. Usually he goes way more.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: When did he last drink anything that stayed down?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Maybe last night? He had some Pedialyte around eight PM and kept it down for a few hours.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Let me take a look at him.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Noah, can you open your mouth for me? Good. His mucous membranes are a bit dry. Skin turgor is slightly decreased. Capillary refill is okay, about two seconds. He's mildly dehydrated but not severely.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Does he need an IV?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Let's try something first. I'm going to give him Zofran, that's an anti-nausea medication. It dissolves on the tongue so he doesn't have to swallow it. Then we'll do an oral rehydration challenge.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: What's that?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: We'll give him small amounts of Pedialyte, about a teaspoon every few minutes, and see if he can keep it down. If the Zofran works and he tolerates the fluids, you can go home and continue that at home.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: And if he can't keep it down?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Then we'll need to start an IV for fluids. He might need to stay for observation or even be admitted depending on how he does.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Okay. What about the vomiting at home? Can I get more of that Zofran?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Yes, I'll prescribe Zofran dissolvable tablets. He can have one every eight hours as needed for the next two to three days.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Should I keep giving Pedialyte or can he have regular fluids?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Start with Pedialyte or diluted juice. Small sips frequently, not big gulps. Once he's keeping that down for a few hours, you can try bland foods like crackers, toast, bananas.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: What if he's still vomiting tomorrow?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: If he can't keep fluids down despite the Zofran, if he has no wet diapers for eight hours or more, if you see blood in his vomit, or if he becomes very lethargic or inconsolable, bring him back or go to the ER.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Could this be something serious? Like appendicitis?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: His exam doesn't suggest appendicitis. His belly is soft, no localized tenderness. This looks like viral gastroenteritis. But if he develops severe abdominal pain, especially on the right side, that would change things.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Do you need to do any labs?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Not right now. If he fails the oral challenge and needs an IV, we'll check electrolytes at that point. But let's see how the Zofran works first.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Okay. Thank you.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I'll have the nurse give him the Zofran now and we'll start the fluid challenge. I'll check back in about 30 minutes.
